text:
There are two ways to think about execution.  

Nonessentialists force execution.  

Essentialists invest their saved time into designing a system.  

This system makes execution almost effortless.  

In chapter 1, we discussed our lives resembling an overly full closet.  

An Essentialist would approach organizing that closet.  

To keep your closet tidy, you need a regular routine.  

You need one large bag for items to throw away.  

You also need a very small pile for items to keep.  

You must know the drop-off location for your local thrift store.  

You need to know the hours of that thrift store.  

You should have a scheduled time to go there.  

Once you’ve figured out which activities to keep, execute them.  

You can’t wait until the closet is bursting at the seams.  

You cannot take superhuman efforts to purge it then.  

You must have a system in place for neatness.  

Keeping it neat should become routine and effortless.  

It is human nature to want to do easy things.  

In this part of the book, you’ll learn how to execute right things.  

Make executing essential things as easy and frictionless as possible.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Essentialists create systems to make the execution of essential tasks effortless, contrasting with Nonessentialists who force execution.
